IN THE COURT OF THE SESSIONS JUDGE,
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM
PRESENT : SMT. NAZEERA.S, SESSIONS JUDGE
On Tuesday, 4" day of March 2025/13" day of Phalguna, 1946.
Criminal M.C.No. 629/2025
Crime No 325/2025 of Venjaramood Police Station
Petitioner/Accused No. 1 :-

Aseem S aged 27 years S/o. Shamsheer

Kunnil Veedu Nedumkaitha Koonanvenga P.O

Pullampara Village Nedumangadu Taluk

By Advocate:- S Y Mohan Kumar Kiran
Counter Petitioners :-

1. State of Kerala
2. Station House Officer

Venjaramoodu Police Station

By Public Prosecutor Dr. T. Geenakumari

This Criminal M.C. is coming on for hearing on 03.03.2025 and the court
on 04.03.2025 passed the following

ORDER

This is an application filed under Section 482 of the Bharatiya Nagarik
Suraksha Sanhita, seeking pre-arrest bail.

2. The petitioner is alleged to have committed the offences punishable
under Sections 126, 296(b), 118(1) and 324, r/w Section 3(5) of the Bharatiya
Nyaya Sanhita, and Crime No. 325/2025 of Venjaramood Police Station is
registered against the petitioner arraying him as the 1* accused.

2

3. The prosecution allegation in brief is as follows:- On 18.02.2025 at
about 6 p.m., accused Nos. 1 to 3 trespassed into the Provision Store run by
the defacto complainant, situated in Panvoor Village, and demanded cotton
bandage. The defacto complainant informed the accused that cotton bandage is
not available in his shop. Infuriated by this, the accused uttered abusive words
against the defacto complainant and rambled and destroyed the chilly powder
and bakery products kept in the shop, causing a loss of Rs.1,500/- to the defacto
complainant. When the defacto complainant intervened, the 2" accused caught
hold of his collar and the 1* accused fisted him on his forehead, using a sharp
weapon, causing an injury. Thereafter, all the accused repeatedly fisted on the
back and head of the defacto complainant.

4. Notice in this bail application is issued to the Public Prosecutor.
The Investigating Officer filed report opposing the bail application.

5. Heard. Perused the records.

6. The only point to be considered is, whether pre-arrest bail can be
granted to the petitioner/ 1* accused.

7. The Point:- The petitioner / 1° accused along with the other
accused are alleged to have abused the defacto complainant and assaulted him,
and the petitioner/ 1* accused had used a sharp weapon to fist on the forehead
of the defacto complainant, causing injuries. The motive for the alleged

3
incident is the rage that aroused when the defacto complainant told the accused
that the cotton bandage demanded by them is not available in his shop.

8. According to the petitioner, he is innocent of the allegations
levelled against him. It is submitted that, on the fateful day, one Shiju, who is
conducting a stationery store, abused and assaulted the petitioner, and the
petitioner filed a complaint in this regard before the Venjaramoodu Police
Station, and no action was taken so far, and it is thereafter, the defacto
complainant filed a complaint against the petitioner and others and falsely
implicated them in this crime.

9. There is serious allegation as against the petitioner. In the First
Information Statement given by the defacto complainant, it is stated that, the
petitioner/Ist accused along with the other accused had assaulted the defacto
complainant, and in that process, the petitioner / 1* accused had fisted on his
forehead using a sharp weapon, causing an injury. In the body note with the
First Information Statement, it is noted that, the defacto complainant had wound
over forehead and pain on back. So, there is corresponding injuries. So, the
prosecution has made out a prima facie case against the petitioner/ 1 accused
and regarding the involvement of the petitioner in the alleged offence. It is
stated in the report that, the ring used for the commission of the offence is to be
recovered, and the wound certificate of the victim is to be obtained. The
investigation is progressing. Considering the facts stated in the report to the

4

effect that the petitioner is involved in the offence, it appears that exceptional
jurisdiction to grant a pre-arrest bail cannot be exercised in this case.

10. In Jai Prakash Singh v. State of Bihar and Another (2012 (4)
SCC 379), the Hon’ble Apex court has held that, an order of pre-arrest bail
being an extra ordinary privilege, should be granted only in exceptional cases. It
is settled in law that arrest should be the last option and it should be restricted to
cases where arrest is imperative in the facts and circumstances of a case and
consistent view is that the grant of anticipatory bail shall be restricted to
exceptional circumstances. So it is clear that the power to grant anticipatory bail
under section 482 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita. is an exceptional
power and should be exercised only in exceptional cases and not as a matter of
course. Its object is to ensure that a person should not be harassed or humiliated
in order to satisfy the grudge or personal vendetta of the complainant. [Reliance
placed on the decision rendered by the Hon’ble Apex Court in HDFC Bank
Limited v. J.J. Mannan and Another (2010 (1) SCC 679); Srikant Upadhyay
v. State of Bihar (2024 KHC Online 6137)]. In the case at hand, I find no
exceptional circumstance to exercise the exceptional power of granting
anticipatory bail.

11. Considering the serious allegation against the petitioner and gravity
of the offence, it appears that granting the petitioner with an order of
anticipatory bail will adversely affect the investigation. If an order of

5
anticipatory bail is granted he is likely to influence the witnesses and tamper
with the evidence. Considering all these aspects, this court is not inclined to
grant an order of pre-arrest bail to the petitioner.
In the result, this petition is dismissed.
Dictated to the Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by him, corrected and
pronounced by me in Open Court on this the 4" day of March, 2025
Sd/-
NAZEERA S.
SESSIONS JUDGE
